item.title: Moparscape - Scripting API: Resources
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

A lot of API objects are a 1:1 representation in Lua so I follow this styling guide:

https://github.com/Olivine-Labs/lua-style-guide

However to differentiate between application methods and script methods I use snake case versus lowercase writing conventions.

Read full topic

item.title: Moparscape - Scripting API: Resources
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:14, topic:550942”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=669855.msg4479843#msg4479843 date=1428811902]

Lua really isn’t that bad of a language, the basics aren’t hard to conquer coming from Java or C#. It can get confusing coming from those when you get into things like meta tables and what not. Sini has a point, these scripting languages are meant, in these instances, for this type of application. These languages are actually easier to handle and to keep track of overall, just might be kind of hard to see, especially in a community of people who have never done anything other than Java.
[/quote]there is no world in which a scripting language is going to be easier to “keep track of” than a language like java, especially with how advanced compiled-language IDEs are (unless I completely misunderstand what you mean by “keep track of”). the plain and simple truth is that you use a scripting language to speed up development. if in the end you aren’t saving development time by using a scripting language then you might as well use a java plugin system

everything other argument ( like how ugly it is to store data in java with enums and such vs easy to read ruby maps) can be worked around with the compiled language (json for example)

I’d wager it takes 40% less time to script content than write it in java. Easily. And write it incrementally in a clean manner.[/quote]A lot of that comes down to the way your content is designed. The way the source is current written, I wouldn’t doubt that for a second. But there are things you can do to speed up java content development. One of them is of course is the design pattern. Look at something like matrix, it may have a weird and pretty bad content design pattern, but just from looking you can tell its a hellavu lot faster to write than content in the current base. And secondly IDE snippets/content prediction are individually huge, but not as useful as scripting (because obviously there’s a difference between one person having speedier writing vs everyone). I am in awe when I watch people that have been using their API/project for a while in their IDE and how fast they can write their code. You could have something like ‘giveitem’ translate to your big long java code to somewhat replicate scripting even. I wish I had that setup with my IDE

Read full topic

item.title: Moparscape - Scripting API: Resources
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:12, topic:550942”][quote author=tyb97 link=topic=669855.msg4479837#msg4479837 date=1428809449]
Lua really isn’t that bad of a language, the basics aren’t hard to conquer coming from Java or C#. It can get confusing coming from those when you get into things like meta tables and what not. Sini has a point, these scripting languages are meant, in these instances, for this type of application. These languages are actually easier to handle and to keep track of overall, just might be kind of hard to see, especially in a community of people who have never done anything other than Java.
[/quote]there is no world in which a scripting language is going to be easier to “keep track of” than a language like java, especially with how advanced compiled-language IDEs are (unless I completely misunderstand what you mean by “keep track of”). the plain and simple truth is that you use a scripting language to speed up development. if in the end you aren’t saving development time by using a scripting language then you might as well use a java plugin system

everything other argument ( like how ugly it is to store data in java with enums and such vs easy to read ruby maps) can be worked around with the compiled language (json for example)[/quote]

I’d wager it takes 40% less time to script content than write it in java. Easily. And write it incrementally in a clean manner.

Read full topic

item.title: Moparscape - Scripting API: Resources
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:12, topic:550942”][quote author=tyb97 link=topic=669855.msg4479837#msg4479837 date=1428809449]
Lua really isn’t that bad of a language, the basics aren’t hard to conquer coming from Java or C#. It can get confusing coming from those when you get into things like meta tables and what not. Sini has a point, these scripting languages are meant, in these instances, for this type of application. These languages are actually easier to handle and to keep track of overall, just might be kind of hard to see, especially in a community of people who have never done anything other than Java.
[/quote]there is no world in which a scripting language is going to be easier to “keep track of” than a language like java, especially with how advanced compiled-language IDEs are (unless I completely misunderstand what you mean by “keep track of”). the plain and simple truth is that you use a scripting language to speed up development. if in the end you aren’t saving development time by using a scripting language then you might as well use a java plugin system

everything other argument ( like how ugly it is to store data in java with enums and such vs easy to read ruby maps) can be worked around with the compiled language (json for example)[/quote]
By keep track of I meant it with packaging and file organization mainly, there isn’t many restrictions to how you organize all of this, i.e several different files and folders, since ultimately however you write how it is interpreted handles what you can and can’t do as far as that goes. And at least in my own opinion, a scripting language is easier to learn than your regular high-level OOP language, so somebody who isn’t very good at Java, because he is a beginner, or can’t quite grasp the concepts, could find it easier to write it in Lua, or something. In theory at least.

Read full topic

item.title: Moparscape - Scripting API: Resources
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

I think once people overcome the Lua learning curve, which is small in my opinion, they will come to find that writing content is a breeze and fun. That’s why I released the videos to give an example of this. And funnily enough behind this API you’re not limited to Lua but that’s what I want to enforce for the server.

Read full topic

item.title: Moparscape - Scripting API: Resources
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:8, topic:550942”][quote author=Rodgerwilco link=topic=669855.msg4479804#msg4479804 date=1428801594]
Look at the awesome responses due to the new scripting language impl. I think you would have more people willing to write scripts if you just kept it in java.
[/quote]

And I think I’ll reiterate the question of why don’t people get it through their skulls that java is NOT a good language to write all this content in.[/quote]That’s an opinion m8, plenty of big servers have loads of content all in java w/o performance issues (which of course all comes down to how your content is designed, its somewhat funny that the poorer designs actually can show performance increases, and also it has been shown that certain scripting interfaces such as jruby are just flat out slower than pure java), people script to write faster and some people dont weigh that speed over having to learn the language

Of course with that said I personally find it interesting and look forward to trying my hand at writing plugins

Read full topic

item.title: Moparscape - Scripting API: Resources
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

Rodgerwilco:

Look at the awesome responses due to the new scripting language impl. I think you would have more people willing to write scripts if you just kept it in java.

And I think I’ll reiterate the question of; why don’t people get it through their skulls that java is NOT a good language to write all this content in? What advantages does Java pose as a language for people to script in, other than, it’s well known in the community. A lot of good language practices do not align for ease of access in terms of how content should be written and there are too many variables to couple with content logic in a clean and efficient manner, especially since you want to avoid global state while most scripting languages like Javascript, Lua, and Ruby either have support for globally scoped variables or actually encourage them.

I’m not catering to all of you. I’m catering to those of you who are willing and skilled enough to take advantage of the utility this gives you.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:4, topic:550942”][quote author=sinisoul link=topic=669855.msg4479136#msg4479136 date=1428398291]

Looking pretty snazzy. Are the scripts currently working or is what you have just the outline?

I want to get everything in place before I turn people loose to write content
[/quote]I think what he’s asking is do you have any of the bindings written yet or is it just the lua skeleton atm, because obviously:

[tt]public void chatnpc(String message) {}[/tt]

wont do anything :P[/quote]

I want to finish all the methods I need will be needed before writing the code. Writing the code is the easy part, I already have the systems in place.

Read full topic
